chunk.text: riptions yield identical predictions outside of this restricted region, notably at Qr > ES, where our NLO perturbative expression P(Q, Qr, y,.) in the gg + gg channel is controlled only by quasi-experimental isolation and coincides with the corresponding direct cross section in DIPHOX. The default subtraction prescription predicts a vanishing do/dQr in the extreme Qr — 0 limit, while the smooth-cone prescription has an integrable singularity in this limit, avoided by an explicit small-Qr cutoff in the calculation of our Y-piece. Both prescriptions are free of the logarithmic singularity at Q; = E%$° arising in the fixed-order (DIPHOX) calculation. Another class of large radiative corrections arises when the yy invariant mass Q is smaller than the yy transverse momentum QT. In this case, one final-state quark or gluon fragments into a low-mass yy pair, e.g. as g+g > (q¢ frag yy) + g. The lowest-order contributions of this kind are shown in Fig. The process is described by a 7y-fragmentation func- tion D,,(21, 22,4), different from the single-photon fragmentation function D,(z, 4).
